loans.name: Tawab Qasemy Group

texts.en:
Ghancha is the group leader of the Tawab Q. group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for her/his business. Ghancha is a married woman with four children. She wants to take a loan for her husband's business of selling dried fruits. He wants to make his business better.

Bibi Sema wants to take a loan for her business, which is performing tailoring in her house. After the loan, she wants to make a new shop for her business and buy necessary items for her business. 

A. Tawob wants to take a loan for his business of selling clothes. He wants to buy original clothes for his shop and wants to expand and progress his business.

They want to thank all lenders for this process in Afghanistan. And they also thank the AFSG for supporting poor people.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Arghwan Group

texts.en:
Shayma is the group leader of the Arghwan group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for her/his business. Shayma is 27 years old and single. She wants to take a loan for her brother’s general store business. He wants to buy oil, rice, tea and other things for his business.

Zakera wants to take a loan for her father’s business selling vegetables from a cart. He wants to take a new shop for his business and his main purpose is to support his family in a better way.  Halema wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She needs many new and required materials for her tailoring.

They would like to thank both AFS and Kiva lenders who support the people around the world through their effective process.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for the general store

loans.name: Hamasa-E One Group

texts.en:
This is Hamasa-e one group. This group is made up of three members. Sedeqa is the group leader. She is 40 years old, married, and has six children: four sons and two daughters. She wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling clothes from a cart. Her husband is old, so his son supports him as well. 
These three members have requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani. Rahmatullah, who is the second member of Hamasa-e one group, has a business selling mobile cards. He supports his family members using the income from his business. His purpose in getting a loan is to expand his business. The last member is Hamasa who is a tailor. Since the Taliban regime, she has been sewing clothes because at that time they had lots of economic problems. Now with the Kiva loan, she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business in a new way to support her husband and children.
They all would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel I. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Anabel owns and operates a business using her van to provide transport services to local community members. She is just starting this business. In 2005, Anabel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. Anabel is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen P. is from the village of Macabayao, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Helen owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500.00 PHP a month. In 2008, Helen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Helen is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pigs

loans.name: Jovelita

texts.en:
Jovelita B. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 35 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Jovelita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as candies, some food for snacks, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Jovelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Jovelita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:

She is just starting this business. In 2009, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Gina is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Moeun P. is a widow and a good mother to two children. One child still attends school, while the other child works as a truck driver. To help contribute to the family’s income, Moeun P. distills traditional white wine out of her home, which she then sells. In addition, Moeun P. uses the leftover distilled wine to feed a few pigs for extra revenue. She is able to make $7.66 each day, which she uses to help her family’s financial crisis and ensure that her school-aged child attains the highest level of education. Moeun P. is taking out her loan to purchase food and ten piglets to breed.

loans.use: To purchase food and ten piglets to breed.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is 46 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Huvsgul province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Narantuya operates a dairy retail business at the local food market. She began her business nine years ago. Since then, she has stabilized her business operations and has built a strong customer base. She would like to expand her business and be able to save money so that she can improve both her and her family’s quality of life. She is requesting a 800,000 tugrug (approximately 550 USD) loan in order to purchase a variety of dairy products for the upcoming winter months.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of dairy products.

loans.name: Orsoo

texts.en:
Orsoo is 65 years old and lives with his wife and 27-year-old son in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. He lives with his family in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son attends university. Orsoo owns and operates his own wooden product business, specializing in ger parts, ger furniture, and other larger furniture pieces. He started his business in 1990. Most of his profits come from the sale of his larger-sized furniture. All of his products are made with great care and attention to detail, which has earned him a reputation among his customers as a quality furniture provider. He would like to increase his sales so that he can afford his family's living expenses.

Orsoo is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (approximately 2,800 USD) loan to purchase more wood so that he can increase the number and the variety of large furniture pieces that he can sell in order to pay for his son's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make large furniture pieces.

loans.name: Togmid

texts.en:
Togmid is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest daughter, 17, is in college while the youngest, 5, is in kindergarten.

With the help of his wife, Togmid operates a business selling secondhand shoes out of a shipping container at a local market. He began his business in 2004 after working in a mining company for several years.

Togmid is planning to continue to maintain his business for the future. He says, "My dream is to find a proper jobs for my children and to help them to better their quality of life."

Togmid is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase shoes for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more used shoes

loans.name: Tsedenbal

texts.en:
Tsedenbal is 30 years old and lives with his wife and 4-year-old son in Uvs province, Mongolia. His son is in kindergarten while his wife operates a milk-trading business.

Tsedenbal operates a raw material business in his town where he sells things like sheep and goat skins. He started his business in 2004 with the help of his brother and enabled himself to buy a car in order to start a taxi service as well. His raw material business is the most profitable in October and November when Mongolians prepare meat that will be eaten during the winter.

Tsedenbal would eventually like to expand his house as his children get older so that the family can be more comfortable. He says, “I want to save enough money for my children’s education.”

Tsedenbal is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more raw materials for the upcoming busy season.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Eden

texts.en: Eden E. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Eden owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Eden joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: 01-Dong Hai Group

texts.en: Yen T. P. is a 64-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Yen is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 01-Dong Hai. Yen is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Yen operates a family member's service-based business venture. The main source of income for the business comes from providing photography services to local community members. Yen has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2.000.000 Vietnamese Dong a month from these activities. In 2007, Yen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Yen from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Yen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. T. T. Cat is a 62-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her general store. 2. N. T. Hop is a 28-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food. 3. L. T. Ha is a 27-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her clothing business. 4. L. T. Giao is a 60-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 5. T. T. Tam is a 47-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food. 6. D. T. Thanh is a 27-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her general store. 7. H. T. Tam is a 38-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food. 8. L. T. Huong is a 33-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Yen T. P. (41) là 64 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Yen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 9 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 01-Dong Hai (16-16-01). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ chụp hình cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương. Yen thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Yen kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND. Vào 2007, Yen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Yen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. T. Cat (21) là 62 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. 2. N. T. Hop (13) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. L. T. Ha (35) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo. 4. L. T. Giao (1) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 5. T. T. Tam (14) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 6. D. T. Thanh (6) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. 7. H. T. Tam (26) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 8. L. T. Huong (46) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en: Elmer S. is from the village of Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. He is 52 years old. Elmer is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Elmer operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motor services to transport passengers in the local community. Elmer has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Elmer joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elmer is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Elmer from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Martiza's Group

texts.en: Martiza M. is from the town of San Dionicio, MadD., Quirino. She is 51 years old. Martiza is the group leader of a 26-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Martiza M.'s group. Martiza is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Martiza owns and operates a furniture-making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Martiza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 30,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Martiza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Martiza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the first loan taken out by Martiza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: 16-02 Dong Hai Group

texts.en: Tinh Nguyen Thi is a 53-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Tinh is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02-Dong Hai. Tinh is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Tinh raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Tinh has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3.000.000 Vietnamese Dong a month from these activities. In 2004, Tinh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tinh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the ninth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Tinh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Le Thi Lam is a 53-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 2. Le Thi Thuy is a 46-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food. 3. Nguyen Thi Thoi is a 41-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her butcher shop. 4. Tran Thi Tam is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her food stall. 5. Duong Thi Huong is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 6. Nguyen Thi Do is a 43-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to raise livestock. 7. Le Thi Trung is a 54-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to raise livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Tinh Nguyen Thi (8) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Tinh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 8 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02-Dong Hai (16-06-02). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ trồng & thu hoạch gạo để bán. Tinh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Tinh kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND. Vào 2004, Tinh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Tinh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 9th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Le Thi Lam (10) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 2. Le Thi Thuy (5) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. Nguyen Thi Thoi (51) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t. 4. Tran Thi Tam (59) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. Duong Thi Huong (46) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 6. Nguyen Thi Do (12) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 7. Le Thi Trung (49) là 54 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ton

texts.en:
Mrs. Ton S. V. (pictured) was married a long time ago to Heng. They both are the good parents of two kids. Both of the kids are still young and attend the local primary school. Ton S. V. and her husband earn their daily income by cultivating rice and some vegetable crops, which they will sell when the crops mature. In addition to farming, they raise ducks to produce eggs and then sell. 

Ton S. V. wants to improve her duck-raising business, which is the most profitable one for family. She has decided to ask for a loan to purchase more feed and small ducks to breed.

loans.use: To purchase more feed and small ducks to breed

loans.name: Eap

texts.en:
Eap M. is a low-income person living in the Kampong Chhnang province, where she earns money by weaving bamboo baskets. Her husband is a building worker who provides his income to feed the family. This couple was married many years ago and is blessed with four children, one of whom works in construction while the remaining three are going to school. 

Eap M. lacks raw materials to continue weaving baskets. She is asking for a loan to buy bamboo, which she will use to make baskets.

loans.use: To buy bamboo

loans.name: Bermarie

texts.en:
Bermarie T. is from the village of Caputol located in Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Bermarie is married and has seven infant-aged children. To make a living, Bermarie owns & operates a business transporting local community members around the various neighborhoods. Bermarie has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Bermarie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bermarie has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Bermarie is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase parts for her motorcycle needed to provide service. This loan will be the 14th loan taken out by Bermarie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Thuch

texts.en: S. is 21 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang, a province of Cambodia. She is a good housewife who cooks very good meals for her family and cares for her children. She is the mother of two kids who are already enrolled in primary school. To earn a living, S. plants a variety of crops on her own farmland. She then harvests and sells the crops. Her husband works with her on the farm. S. is applying for a loan to use as capital to invest in a new enterprise. She will use her loan to buy rice in bulk from other farmers to resell and gain a profit. This will provide her with additional income and she will use it to ensure that her family attains a better standard of living.

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypich T., 27, and her husband, Mr. Sokhai Khoem, 24, were married in 2008 and have just had a young daughter. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Two about 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sreypich has been a farmer since she was young, while her husband has been a policeman for five years. She is asking for her first loan of $600 to purchase seeds, pesticide, and fertilizer and to pay the plowing fee.

loans.use: To buy seeds, pesticides & fertilizer and to pay for plowing

loans.name: Kimtray

texts.en:
Mr. Kimtray L. (pictured here), 29, and his wife, Mrs. Savy Yan, 30, have been married for more than eight and have three daughters. One of them is in school. They live in a small village off National Road Number Two about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. 


Kimtray has been a mason for more than eight years, while his wife is a garment factory worker. He lives with his parents. Now he wants to live in a separate home, but he does not have money to build his own house. Hence, he is requesting his second loan of US$600 to use for his project.

loans.use: To build his own house

loans.name: Run

texts.en: Run L. was born in 1966 and has been married many years to Mr. Khoeun, age 43, who is a taxi driver. This couple has two school-aged kids. The kids help with the business when they are not studying. To make a living, Run L. cooks and sells porridge to her neighbors for a profit. She starts selling her items in the morning and finishes in the afternoon.  Run L. is taking out her first loan to purchase a piece of farmland in a good location for farming. On her land she will grow different kinds of crops, from which she will get more proceeds that she will feed her family.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland

loans.name: Marites' Group

texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marites is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhorn R., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Nimol Peang, 30, live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1991 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of the children attends school and the other two are still young.  

Sokhorn has been a farmer for 18 years. He grows corn and tomatoes. His wife has been selling vegetable for two years. She buys some of vegetables from other farmers in her village and some her husband grew and transports to sell in Bek Chan market about 40 kilometers from her house. 

Sokhorn is applying for his first loan of $600 to purchase a cart for his wife to carry vegetables that are for sale.

loans.name: Zain Al Abdeen

texts.en:
Zain A. Abdeen is a 45-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his spouse and their four children. Zain A. Abdeen has been working in agriculture for over 25 years. He owns livestock. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to increase his livestock. This is the first time that Zain A. Abdeen has requested a loan from A. Majmoua.

His clients are his friends and neighbors. Zain A. Abdeen got into this business after taking over his family’s business.

loans.use: To increase his livestock.

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
Melita O. is from the village of Holy Friday. She is 50 years old. Melita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Melita owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from transportation services. Melita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Melita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Melita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will also be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Melita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ernylita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ernylita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ernylita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Ernylita from ASKI. To make a living, Rodolfo owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from motorcycle transport. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mrs. Neang K. is currently a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, located about nineteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She owns a handicraft business whose main activity is making baskets, from which she earns a living. Neang K. has been married for many years to Chay Ly, and they have eight children, half of whom are married and live independently while the others are single. Neang K. is assisted by her husband in weaving bamboo baskets. Neang K. needs a loan to buy more raw materials for her weaving business. Note: the picture shows Neang K.'s husband.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials.

loans.name: Miradil

texts.en: Miradil M. was born in 1955. He is married and has two children. Miradil and his family live in the Fuzuli region. He has been in the business of selling shoes and clothing for five years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to expand his display area with the purpose of improving his business.

loans.use: to expand the display area

loans.name: Mercedes' Group

texts.en:
Mercedes S. is from the village of Olango. She is 52 years old. Mercedes is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI, one of Kiva's field partners. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Mercedes is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Mercedes raises pigs to sell. Mercedes has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $110 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sinun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinun M. (pictured here), who is 49 years old, and her husband, Mr. Phan Port, who is 53, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. Four of the children are married and live in separate homes and the other two attend school.   

Sinun has been a silk weaver for thirty years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market.  Mr. Phan Port has been a motor taxi driver for five years. 

Sinun is applying for a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A. is from the village of District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 48 years old, married, and has six adult children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a restaurant where she serves a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $220 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Luzviminda is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as working capital. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Iluminada

texts.en:

She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $113 a month from this activity.

This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Mr. Cheng T., 50, has been operating various enterprises to earn a living. He is a local farmer and also a taxi driver. In addition, he also takes time to fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake for extra profit. His wife assists him in planting crops. 

From his businesses, he can generate around $7 each day, which he uses to feed his family. Cheng T. has four school-aged children. Due to the growing season coming, Cheng T. is looking for a loan as capital to buy fertilizers as well as rice and vegetable seeds to grow.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, rice and vegetable seeds, to grow

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima S. is from the town of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 59 years old. Maxima is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maxima owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maxima has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Maxima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maxima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. Maxima is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maxima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal T., 36, is a horse cart driver, and has been married to Mrs. Bunna Nao, 30, since 1994. They are living on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. His wife sells fish in the local market. 

The house where they stay is old and breaks down. It’s difficult for them to live there. Sophal is asking for his first loan of $600 to add to his own money to build a new house.

loans.use: To add to his own money to build new house.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum R. is 50 years old and the widowed mother of a son who is no longer in school and currently drives a taxi. She was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. To earn a living, Sum R. sells fresh vegetables that she buys from her wholesale supplier. She is typically earning approximately $2 a day. Sum R. will use her loan to increase her vegetable sales. (Sum R. was busy selling her items at the market when the photo was taken, so her son is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To increase her vegetable sales.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia S. is from the village of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 35 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Alicia raises pigs for sale. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $68 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Alicia joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Danilon Marina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $68 a month from this activity.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mr. Phally S., 32, and his wife, Mrs. Sorin Vann, 36, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1996 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of the children are in school.   

The family has three lines of business: producing rice wine, raising pigs and silk weaving. Phally is asking for a loan of $1,000 to continue producing rice wine and raising pigs.

loans.use: To use for producing rice wine and raising pigs.

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El K. is married and blessed with five children. Three of her kids are employed in different occupations, while the other two are studying at the local public school. 

El K. weaves bamboo baskets at her home. She makes many sets of baskets before selling out. She provides her finished baskets to her husband to sell around the community. Recently, the raw material was exhausted. El K. hopes to acquire more, but she doesn’t have money yet to buy it. Thus, she is looking for a loan to purchase bamboo to make more baskets.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo.

loans.name: Pavlo

texts.en:
Pavlo is married with no children yet. He sells baked goods in Khoost town as well as in other small neighboring towns and villages. His family started this business four years ago. They make the bakery items and then sell it both in bulk and at retail. Pavlo is an honest and hardworking person.

Pavlo would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to increase the assortment of his products. He hopes to open another retail business location to increase profits.

loans.use: to increase the assortment

loans.name: Veasna

texts.en:
Mr. Veasna Y. is 21 and single, and lives with his mother and sisters and brothers on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Veasna has been a wooden house builder for two years. He works in his village. He is in the process now of building his own new house, but it is not finished yet. He is requesting a loan of $600 to complete the job.

loans.use: To add to his own money to finish his house building.

loans.name: Kuch

texts.en: Kuch is 45 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, where she built a medium-sized grocery store. In her store, she sells various grocery items to her nearby villagers for a profit. Her husband is a military policeman. This couple now has a child who is married and lives outside the family home. Kuch  will be using her first loan to purchase a motorcycle to use as transportation. She intends to use the remaining money of the loan to add to the financial capital of her grocery store enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and to add to the financial capital of her grocery store

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Mr. Sinat T. is 44 years old. He and his wife, Mrs. Lay Meach, age 40, have been married since 1992 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. All of them attend school. The family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sinat has been a motor taxi driver for ten years. His wife stays at home and does housework. His motorbike is old and does not work well, so he is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to replace his old one.

loans.name: Lors

texts.en:
Lors N. is a 54-year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is married to Mr. Choeun, age 56, who works with her in the farming business. This couple currently owns a cultivating machine that they use for their farming. They also use their machine to plow a nearby farmer’s land for profit.

When the dry season comes, the environment begins drying everywhere. This condition may affect Lors N. in her ability to grow her crops due to the lack of a watering system. She needs a loan to purchase a pump and a machine to irrigate her crops.

loans.use: To purchase a pump and a machine for irrigation

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina E. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Marina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marina provides motorcycle services as a mode of transportation to local community members. Marina is just starting this business.

In 2009, Marina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Marina is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam S., 28, is a busy woman who attempts to earn money from many ventures. She cultivates rice as well as buying it in bulk from other farmers to store in her home. She buys when rice is commanding the lowest price and then sells it to gain income. She is also assisted by her husband in planting rice.

Soam S. has given birth to two small kids, who are still not enrolled in school. Soam S. was not available for the photo, so her husband is pictured instead.

Soam S. is applying for a loan to order buy mature rice from farmers to resell to gain income.

loans.use: To buy mature rice to resell

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is divorced with one grown up daughter. She sells various construction supplies at a downtown market in the city of Zaporozhye. She has been in this business for seven years. She offers good quality products at affordable prices and this factor, as well as a good location, has brought Irina many repeat clients.

Irina would like to borrow 8,700 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventory. She hopes to receive additional income and be able to help her daughter financially.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Pan

texts.en:
Mr. Pan T. and his wife, Mrs. Nary Toun, live along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have seven children: six sons and one daughter. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, one son is an electrician, a daughter works for a factory that produces shoes, and the others attend school.

Pan is a wooden-house builder and his wife is a rice farmer. He is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita D. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marita owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Marita is just starting this business.
In 2009, Marita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Miss. Socheat Y., 29, is single and lives with her mother, sisters and brothers on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Socheat has been a silk weaver for five years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market.

The house where Socheat lives is old and broken down, so she decided to build a new one. But, she doesn’t have money to pay to build it. Hence, she is asking for her first loan of US$1,000 for this purpose.

loans.use: To pay for house construction

loans.name: Nemet

texts.en: Nemet is a 21-year-old single man living in Fuzuli region. As you see in the photo, this young man sells greens. He has been in his business for two years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 Azerbaijani manats to buy fruits and vegetables to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: 12-Dong Son Group

texts.en:
Lan B. T. (251) is a 47-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Lan is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 12-Dong Son (10.13.12 Dong Son).
Lan is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she operates a family member's business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lan has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.
In 2009, Lan joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,963,500 VND from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Lan is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her third from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. Lan plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group
1. P. T. Sau (252) is a 24-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food. 2. T. K. Dung (255) is a 49-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. 3. N. T. Phuong (256) is a 37-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. 4. L. T. Nguyet (254) is a 43-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food. 5. D. T. Chau (253) is a 50-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food. 6. L. T. Ha (266) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.

About Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Lan B. T. (251) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Lan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 12- Dong Son (10.13.12 Dong Son). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa phương. Lan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Lan kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND. Vào 2009, Lan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Lan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.963.500 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. P. T. Sau (252) là 24 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 2. T. K. Dung (255) là 49 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 3. N. T. Phuong (256) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 4. L. T. Nguyet (254) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 5. D. T. Chau (253) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 6. L. T. Ha (266) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nheb

texts.en:
Mrs. Nheb T., 54, and her husband, Mr. Lorn Soun, 59, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1978 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, one weaves silk at home, and other three attend school.

Nheb has been a silk weaver since 1980, a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to become a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market.

Nheb is asking for a loan of $250 to purchase materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen M. is from the village of Unidos. She is 52 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Helen owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling a variety of food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month. In 2004, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Helen is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Abdull Zafar

texts.en:
Abdull Zafar is an educated man with full experience. He has a retail shop where he works and has been operating this business for a long time. He has a small business but has a good number of customers. When he started his business he had fewer materials in his shop.

Now Abdull Zafar has requested a loan of 30,000 Afghani for personal use. He wants to take English and math courses.

Abdull Zafar is very happy about this process of providing small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To pay for English and math courses

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan H. (pictured here), 51, and her husband, Mr. Heng Hor, 53, live on an island on Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1979 and have eight children: two sons and six daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, three live at home, and the other three attend school.
Phan raises pigs at home, while her husband constructs wooden houses. Phan is requesting her first loan of $1,200 USD to purchase additional piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily J. is from the village of Unidos. She is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Emily has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2003, Emily joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Emily is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her twelfth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Abdull Razaq

texts.en:
Abdull Razaq son of Q. is educated and is one of the staff of the government in Afghanistan. He has been involved in this occupation for more than ten years, but he lives in a rental house. With his salary he can support his family and pay the rent of his house, but he can't build a house or buy a house.

A few years ago, Abdull Razaq bought land, but he was unable to build on it. Now he needs a loan to build a house so that he is able to live in his own house. Therefore, he has requested a loan of 50,000 Afghanis to start working on his land to build his new home.

Abdull Razaq hopes to start a new life to help his family better than now and make a bright future for them.

loans.use: To buy some tools to build his new house

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mrs. Soy S. (pictured here), 54, and her husband, Mr. Phin Sin, 55, live on an island on Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1975 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home, two assist their parents in their farming business, and one daughter attends school.
Mrs. Soy S. and her husband are farmers who grow ginger on their farmland in the village. The couple wants to buy piglets for their children to raise. In this way, they will be able to earn extra income to support their family. Therefore, Soy is asking for her first loan of $1,000 USD for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for her children to raise

loans.name: Crispina

texts.en: Crispina O. is from the village of Panalsalan. She is 35 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Crispina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Crispina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Crispina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Daniel Okuku

texts.en: Daniel Okuku Ong’ayo is 30 years old, married, and the father of three children. He is a businessman in Rongo, Kenya. Daniel is a former farmer who decided to venture into retail business, chiefly hawking small items. He buys his stock five times a month from neighboring Kisii town, and often from Nairobi, the capital city. Daniel is requesting a loan of 15,000 KES, which will go towards increasing his stock. His future plan is to start a retail shop business.

loans.use: To increase his stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Susan Adhiambo

texts.en:
Susan Adhiambo M. is a former grocery business woman in the market of Rongo, Kenya.  During the tenure of this business she trained at a tailoring institution and in the year 2002 she started her own tailoring business.

She is married and the mother of 4 children. Her stock order lasts a week so she restocks every week.  Her future plan is to venture into the house construction materials business. She would like a loan of Kshs.10,000.

loans.use: Add to her stock of materials.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary Akoth

texts.en:
Mary Akoth O. is in the business of selling clothes. She started this business back in the year 1985 and has never looked back since. She also considers herself as part of the business backbone of her country. She says this can be judged by her 15 years in business in Rongo market and the surrounding markets.

She is the mother of 5 children and a wife.  She would like a loan of Kshs. 40,000.

loans.use: Increase her clothing stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jimailyn

texts.en: Jimailyn L. is from the village of Bato. She is 30 years old. Jimailyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jimailyn owns & operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from cultivating fruit trees & harvesting the fruit for sale. Jimailyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Jimailyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jimailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Jimailyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Jimailyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: George Otieno

texts.en:
George Otieno A. is a 31-year-old man who is married and the father of two children.

George is the sole owner of a fish business, buying fish at Homabay in Western Kenya and selling it in the coastal towns of Kenya. He used to run a retail shop but abandoned it since, he says, he saw great profits in the fish business.

George needs a loan of Kshs 50,000 which he plans to use to increase his stock of fish.

loans.use: To increase his stock of fish

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adham

texts.en:
Adham is 21 years old and single. He runs a grocery store where he sells sweets (candies), preserved food, juices, soft drinks and other products. The inventory he has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Adham is respectful and patient with all of his customers, and this attracts people and brings them back to his store to buy groceries again.
Adham is seeking to keep his business sustainable and has requested a loan of $2,000 USD to increase the inventory he has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of his business and help Adham reach all of his aspirations.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Wilikister Auma

texts.en:
Wilikister Auma O. is a 38-year-old woman who is separated from her husband. She is the mother of three children of whom she is the custodian. She lives in Rongo District, Kenya.

Wilikister  Auma formerly hawked (sold door-to-door) secondhand clothes but now runs a food business. She buys groundnuts (peanuts) in bulk once a month and then makes local peanut butter for sale around the country.

Wilikister Auma would like a loan of Kshs 30,000 which will go to increasing her stock of groundnuts, hence expanding her business.

Wilikister Auma’s long-term plan, she says, is to guarantee the education of her children.

loans.use: To increase her stock of groundnuts

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dorcas Adhiambo

texts.en: Dorcas Adhiambo O. is a boutique owner. She started her business back in 1995, having graduated from high school a few years earlier and without funds to go to college. She started the business as a means of self-employment and also as a gesture, back then, that women, too, can do business in a male-dominated environment. She is now a widow and a mother of two children. She would like a loan of 50,000 KES, which will go towards increasing the stock in her boutique.

loans.use: To increase the stock in her boutique

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Siprina Agutu

texts.en: Siprina Agutu O. is a businesswoman in the market at Rongo, Kenya, and the mother of six children. For the past three years, she has run a retail business dealing in jaggery, a product of molasses. Jaggery is used in the manufacture of local brews and also taken as candy. Siprina is requesting a loan of 10,000 KES, which will go towards increasing her stock and also her first roll-out plan towards wholesaling the same product.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sope Serigne Babacar Sy Group No. 14

texts.en:
Sope Serigne Babacar Sy is an association of female commercantes (vendors) working in Thies, a city about seventy kilometers from Dakar.

The association, named after an important marabout (a religious leader in West African Islam), was founded in 2006 by a group of entrepreneurial women from the Cité Lamy neighborhood. Their aim was to help the members finance their small businesses through a revolving savings fund called a tontine, in which members contribute a small amount to the pot each month to finance one member's activities.

Today, the association has evolved to secure group loans for its members through cooperation with UIMCEC (Union of Institution Mutualiste Communautaire d’Epargne et de Credit). Groups of five are financed through ten-month loans of which each member receives an equal amount. On the 20th of each month, the members of the association hold a meeting to collect the repayments.
