loans.use: to buy additional stock for his store

loans.name: Nob

texts.en:
Mr. Nob K., 59 years old, lives in Dak Por village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field on which he cultivates rice. His wife, Mrs. Lonn Kep, helps him with the farming. 

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Nob K. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows to start a breeding business. 

Mr. Nob K. is the father of four children, one of whom is a coconut-seller while another one is employed in the garment factory. The others are students in the local school. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy two cows to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Thoeun M. lives in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Nget Pheap, are farmers who own a piece of land on which they cultivate rice to earn a living. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support the family. 

Thus, Mr. Thoeun M. wants to start a new business. He decided to ask for a loan to buy a store at the local market for selling clothes, and he would use the rest of the loan to buy more clothes to re-sell. 

Mr. Thoeun M. is the father of six children, one of whom is a grocer in the local market, while another one is employed in a garment factory. Three others are students in the local school, and the last one is too young to study or work. His wife is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a store at the local market for selling clothes and to buy more clothes to re-sell.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
S. is 35 years old, a married woman, and the good mother of two young kids. Both are going to school and depend on their parents' income. S. owns a small business in which the main activity is decorating wooden furniture. 

Another source of family income is her husband’s enterprise. He is a domestic vehicle trader. Also, he buys vehicles at low cost and then paints and cleans up them and sells them at higher prices.  S. finds that her husband’s business is very profitable and is able to ensure a good standard of living for her family. 

She would like to borrow a $1100 loan for her husband to add to the financial capital of his vehicle sale trade.

loans.use: To add to the financial capital of the vehicle sale trade.

loans.name: Noy

texts.en:
Mrs. Noy C. is a farmer who lives in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. She owns a three-hectare field where she cultivates rice. She is also a pig breeder and makes a small income to support her family. 

Although she tries to work hard with different businesses, she still earns less income than she needs, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows to start a new business. 

Mrs. Noy C. is a widow with two children, both of whom are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy two cows to start a new business.

loans.name: Amen

texts.en:
Amen C. is from the city of Turayong, Cauayan, Isabela. She is 50 years old, married, and has six adult children. To make a living, Amen owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Amen has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $45 weekly.

In 2007, Amen joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Amen is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 47 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $132 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Erlinda joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Erlinda is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem N., 34, is married and lives with her two school-aged children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. N. is engaged in a business of buying rice from local farmers to sell at the market, and she is able to earn an income of about $3 a day to help cover the family expenses. She has been with this business since 2003. 

Her husband buys cows from local farmers and re-sells them at the market, earning an income of about $2 a day. N. and her husband try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well.

As a result, N. is requesting a loan of $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to stock more rice and sell it back when the price is good. This is her first loan from CREDIT. (N. is pictured with her husband in the photo)

loans.use: buy more rice for resale

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean F., 33, is making sure that her family is provided with their daily needs. She is married to Fernando F., a factory worker, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been in the rug-making business for 11 years.

Mary Jean has been a regular member of the Kiva field partner, Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times through CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for her rug-making business.  She is able to earn a profit of about $275 a month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business for buying raw materials like strips of cloth, crayons and sewing thread.

She dreams that through this added capital, her monthly profit will also increase. She prays that someday they will have their own home and that her children will graduate from college. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like strips of cloth, crayons and sewing thread.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia G. is from the village of Santa Isabel. She is 39 years old, married, and has one school-age child. To make a living, Emelia owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emelia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $66 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Emelia joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Emelia is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abdel Latif

texts.en: Abdel Latif has owned a photography shop since 2005 and has eleven years of experience in this market. He's married with three children. He works upon request at weddings and special events. Today, Abdel Latif is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy a special camera and other photography tools.

loans.use: buy a special camera and photography tools

loans.name: Charb

texts.en:
Charb O. is married and lives with her four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. O. is engaged in a business of selling bananas at a local market in the town, and she is able to earn an income of about $3 a day to help cover the family expenses. She has been with this business since 2000. 

Her husband sells Cambodian hand-made drums at a nearby province, earning an income of about $2 a day. O. and her husband try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family, and they are seeking to improve their businesses as well. 

As a result, O. is requesting a loan of $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport drums to sell at the market. This is her first loan from CREDIT. (O. is pictured with her family in the photo)

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim O., 54, is married and her husband died several years ago. She now has a single daughter who helps her with the making of traditional pans and cookers to sale. She learned from her grandparents, who were died many years ago, the skill of making cookware. Kim buys clay in bulk for making her pans and cookers and stores it in her home. She makes and saves up many sets of products before selling to buyers. Kim O. plans to build a new house but the constructiO. process has not started due to the lack of funds to buy constructiO. material. In order to start building a new house, Kim O. has requested a loan to buy the required articles.

loans.use: To buy construction materials.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is an 18-year-old single man. In 2008, he decided to start his own business by opening a small mini market specialized in buying chicken and beef. Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy a refrigerator and additional merchandise in order to attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and additional merchandise

loans.name: Morry

texts.en:
Morry L. S., 43, is a mother who cares greatly for her family. Married to Ramon S., a driver and a coconut vendor, they are blessed with four children. She helps her husband earn their income so that their family can have a better life.  She and Ramon have been selling coconuts for 11 years.

Morry has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than five years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used all the money she borrowed to buy more coconuts for her business. Her business lets her earn a profit PHP 8,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital in expanding her business by buying more coconuts.

She dreams that her business will grow so that they will have enough finances for their children's schooling. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of coconuts.

loans.name: 16.02.01 Dong Hai Group

texts.en:
"Huong B. T. Q. (117) is a 29 year-old woman who lives in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Huong is the group leader of a 7-member loan group provided by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 01 Dong Hai (16.02.01 Dong Hai).

Huong is married and has 2 infant-aged children.  To making a living, Huong owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing new clothing services to local community members.  Huong has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Huong joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Huong has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.963.500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.  The loan will be the 7th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Huong plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Lê Thị Thảo  (18) is a 63 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2.  Nguyễn Thị Hồng (69) is a 29 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

3.  Lê Thị Huệ (122) is a 39 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

4.  Nguyễn Thị Huyền  (123) is a 51 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

5.  Lê Thị Ngọc (112) is a 30 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

6.  Trần Thị Nga (120) is a 28 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & increased working capital

loans.name: Lilia's Group

texts.en:
Lilia C. is from the village of Minallo. She is 50 years old. Lilia is the group leader of a 5-member  loan group offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lilia C..

Lilia is married. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling eggs in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ali Zakariya

texts.en:
Ali Zakariya is a 27-year-old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Beirut, the capitA. of Lebanon.

Ali Zakariya has owned a butcher shop since 1999 and is speciA. in his work because he does it well and offers a good quality of meat. He decided on doing his business because he took after his family’s work; therefore he didn’t face difficulties because he was already known in his region and had his faithful clients.

Ali Zakariya requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a van for his work since he delivers to his clients who are people from his region and his surroundings. This is his fourth loan and he has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him improve his shop by purchasing required tools and machines for his work.

In the future, Ali Zakariya plans on expanding his work by opening another shop.

loans.use: To purchase a van for his work

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 30 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Ali has owned and operated an Internet café for ten years. He also repairs computers and sells computer accessories. People from his region know Ali well because he has a good reputation and they feel comfortable coming to his shop. His clients are people from his region, but mainly students and tourists. Ali decided to get into this business because he has experience in computers and likes working with them. Ali requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new computers for his café. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. His plan for the future is to keep on improving his shop.  He has some original ideas to keep on attracting more clients.

loans.use: To purchase new computers for his café

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza A. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Riza owns and operates a business providing motor services in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Riza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Riza is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in her business. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her motorcycle

loans.name: Eugenia

Eugenia L. is from the city of San Fermin, Cauayan, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Eugenia is married and has 4 school-aged children. Eugenia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing products in the local community. Eugenia has been involved in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Eugenia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eugenia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Eugenia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela B., 57, is a hard working single mom. She makes sure that she provides enough for her family so that they can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for 20 years. She also has her own barbeque stand for extra income.

Angela has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow 11 times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy added stock for her variety store. Her business lets her earn a net profit of PHP 8,800 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital by buying assorted grocery items for her expanding business. 

She prays for good health so that she will have the energy to manage her developing business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy assorted grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en: Rabih has worked as a bread distributor since 2007. He delivers bread in his town and its surroundings. He's become well known in the whole region, with customers who await his passage daily. Today, Rabih is asking to borrow $1,200 to change his van motor for easier pick-up and transport to the houses.

loans.use: To change his van motor

loans.name: Teresa's Group

texts.en:
Teresa P. is from the village of Santa Isabel. She is 45 years old. Teresa is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Teresa P..

Teresa is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making vinegar to sell in the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Teresa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell

loans.name: Lika

texts.en: Mrs. Lika L., who lives in Damnak village in Takeo province, is 43 years old. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land for growing rice to support her family. Moreover, she is a pig breeder who owns a lot of piglets. As a breeder, she has a problem because she does not have enough money to support her piglets. Thus, Mrs. Lika L. decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food and piglets. With the rest of the loan, she would buy a cow. Her husband, Mr. Dan Ket, is a construction laborer who can earn a little money to support the family. This couple has two children, one of whom is attending local public school and the other one is too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets

loans.name: Jaafar

texts.en: Jaafar is a 34-year-old married man with one unemployed child. He has been working in computer maintenance since 1999. Today, Jaafar is requesting to borrow $1,200 to renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: To renovate his shop

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet B. is from the city of San Fermin, Cauayan, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Juliet is married. To make a living, Juliet owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from tailoring. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Juliet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita R. is from the village of Santa Isabel. She is 42 years old, married, and has school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.
Anita joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhorn C. is 52 years old and lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo Province. She is a widow with four children, two of whom are farmers while the other two attend the local public school.
Chhorn is a farmer who owns a 2.9-hectare piece of land for cultivating rice. In this plantation, she faces some problems because her field is infertile and it is far from an irrigation system. Therefore, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, a water machine and, with the rest of the loan, she needs to buy fuel.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, a water machine and fuel

loans.name: Mary Kim

texts.en:
Mary Kim D. P. is from Migcanaway, Tangub City. She is 24 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Mary Kim owns and operates a business raising fish for sale (she has a fishpond). She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mary Kim joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Mary Kim is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
Saleh has worked as a builder since 2007. Working on a freelance basis he manages a part of house projects in his village and its surroundings. He's married with three young children who still go to school.

Today, Saleh is requesting $1,200 to buy a wood support for his work.

loans.use: To buy a wood support

loans.name: Rovelyn

texts.en:
Rovelyn D. is from Maquilao, Tangub City. She is 31 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rovelyn owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. Rovelyn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Rovelyn joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rovelyn is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Lon

texts.en:
Mrs. Lon P., who lives in Snuol Khpos village in Takeo province, is 40 years old. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a silk weaver.

Since her silk-weaving business is going well, Mrs. Lon P. needs a loan to expand it by purchasing more silk and to hire weaving laborers.

Mrs. Lon P. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a silk weaver while the other is too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To purchase more silk and to hire workers
